questions.text: Thickest nerve in the human body is
questions.solution:
Sciatic nerve is the thickest nerve of the human body that is the principal continuation of all the roots of the sacral plexus.

  • Formed in the pelvis from the ventral rami of the fourth lumbar to third sacral spinal nerves, it is typically 2 cm wide at its origin and is the thickest nerve in the body.
  • The tibial nerve is derived from the anterior divisions of the sacral plexus, and the common fibular nerve is made up of the posterior divisions of the plexus.
  • It enters the lower limb via the greater sciatic foramen inferior to piriformis and descends between the greater trochanter and ischial tuberosity.
  • In its descent along the posterior thigh, it is crossed by the long head of biceps femoris and divides into the tibial and common fibular (peroneal) nerves proximal to the knee.

Cranial nerves:

  • Shortest cranial nerve – Olfactory nerve
  • Longest cranial nerve – Vagus nerve
  • Thickest cranial nerve – trigeminal nerve
  • Longest intradural course – abducent nerve
  • Trochlear nerve:
    • Thinnest/smallest cranial nerve
    • Only cranial nerve with Dorsal exit
    • Longest intracranial course
    • Only nerve with internal decussation

Greater occipital nerve is the thickest cutaneous nerve in human body.

questions.text: The most common site for gestational Pemphigoid is:
questions.solution:
The most common site of involvement in gestational Pemphigoid/Herpes Gestationis is the Periumblical region.

  • Herpes Gestationis or Gestational Pemphigoid is a variant of pemphigus in pregnancy presenting in the 2nd and 3rd trimester.
  • Begins typically around the umbilical area and spreads to involve the whole abdomen and trunk.
  • It resolves spontaneously after pregnancy.

Pemphigoid Gestationis:

questions.text: Longest acting SSRI is
questions.solution:
Fluoxetine is the longest acting SSRI.

Fluoxetine has plasma t1/2 of 48-72 hours.

It is metabolized to an active product, norfluoxetine, which may have plasma concentrations greater than those of fluoxetine.

The elimination half-life of norfluoxetine is about three times longer than fluoxetine (180 hours) and contributes to the longest half-life of all the SSRIs.

As a result, fluoxetine has to be discontinued 4 weeks or longer before an MAOI can be administered to mitigate the risk of serotonin syndrome.

questions.text: Inhalational agent with most rapid induction and recovery among the given agents is
questions.solution:
Desflurane has the most rapid induction and recovery among the given options.

Blood gas partition coefficient/ Ostwald coefficient for blood–gas:

  • The coefficient is defined as the ratio of the concentration in blood to the concentration in gas that is in contact with that blood, when the partial pressure in both compartments is equal. 
  • It is used to describe the solubility of inhaled general anesthetics in blood.
  • The more soluble the inhaled anesthetic is in blood compared to in the air, the more it binds to plasma proteins in the blood and the higher the blood–gas partition coefficient.
  • It is inversely related to induction rate i.e. agents with high blood gas partition coefficient have slow rate of induction and vice versa.

Blood gas partition coefficient of different anesthetic agents:

Gas Blood gas partition coefficient
Desflurane 0.42
N2O 0.47
Sevoflurane 0.65
Isoflurane 1.4
Halothane 2.4

Thus xenon has a coefficient between 0.13 to 0.2 and has the most rapid induction and recovery followed by desflurane.

questions.text: Earliest finding in compartment syndrome is
questions.solution: Increasing pain that is out of proportion to the injury and worsens with passive stretching of the involved muscles is an early indication that a compartment syndrome is developing.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most alkaline secretion?
questions.solution:
The most alkaline secretion is Brunner’s gland secretion with a pH of 8.0 – 8.9.  

Brunner’s gland is located in the first few centimeters of the duodenal wall. It secretes large amounts of alkaline mucus in response to tactile stimuli on the duodenal mucosa, vagal stimulation, and GI hormones, especially secretin. It is inhibited by sympathetic stimulation.

The function of the mucus secreted by Brunner’s glands is to protect the duodenal wall from digestion by the highly acidic gastric juice emptying from the stomach.

Note: The second most alkaline secretion in the GI tract is the pancreatic juice.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presents with a history of fatigue, dark-coloured urine and photosensitivity. He consumes alcohol regularly. On examination, hyperpigmentation and scarring are present on the face and dorsum of the hand. Lab findings are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb: 7.4 mg/dl
Peripheral blood picture: Suggestive of microcytic hypochromic anaemia
Urinary porphobilinogen level: Normal
Urinary uroporphyrin level: Increased
questions.solution:
A middle-aged adult presenting with features of hemolysis and photosensitivity with elevated urine uroporphyrin suggests a diagnosis of porphyria cutanea tarda.

Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) is the most common porphyria. It is caused by the deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase, which converts uroporphyrinogen III to coproporphyrinogen III.  It is characterized by photosensivity, which manifests as blistering skin lesions on the back of the hands with crusting and scarring. It is associated with hemochromatosis and patients may develop chronic liver disease. There is increased excretion of uroporphyrin in the urine.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

(ALADP)

(CEP)

(UROS)

Severe photosensitivity with erythema, swelling and blistering, hemolytic anemia, splenomegaly
Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT)

(HCP)

(CPOX)

(VP)

Erythropoietic protoporphyria
(EPP)

(FECH)

Non-blistering Photosensitivity with skin lesions
 
Most porphyrias are autosomal dominant except:
  • ALAD enzyme deficiency porphyria
  • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria
  • Erythropoietic protoporphyria
  • X-linked protoporphyria

questions.text: What are the minimum and maximum values established for the calculation of the life expectancy index in HDI?
questions.solution:
The minimum value established for the calculation of the life expectancy index in HDI is 20 years and the maximum is 85 years.

These minimum and maximum values are used to calculate the dimension indices in HDI and are called goalposts.

Each dimension index is calculated using the formula:

Dimension Index = (Actual Value - Minimum Value)/(Maximum Value - Minimum Value).  

Related Pearl: HDI vs. PQLI

 

Human Development Index (HDI)

 Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI)
Components

Longevity (Life expectancy at birth)

A decent standard of living (Real GNI per capita in PPP US$)

Knowledge (mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling)

Life expectancy at 1 year of age 

Infant Mortality rate

Literacy rate
Range 0 to +1 0 to 100

questions.text: Which of the following atypical antipsychotics has the highest risk of galactorrhea?
questions.solution:
Among atypical antipsychotics, risperidone, paliperidone and amisulpride have a higher risk of galactorrhoea.

Tuberoinfundibular neurons project from the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus to the anterior pituitary. Dopamine is delivered in this region via the hypophyseal vessels. Dopamine binds to the D2 receptors present on the lactotropes in the anterior pituitary, and tonically inhibits the prolactin secretion from these cells. 

The more potent a D2 blocking drug is, the more likely it is to cause hyperprolactinemia. All first-generation antipsychotic drugs cause hyperprolactinemia due to their D2 blocking properties. Among the atypical antipsychotics, risperidone, paliperidone, and amisulpride are associated with hyperprolactinemia. Hyperprolactinemia can induce breast engorgement, galactorrhea, and infertility in women, and sexual dysfunction in men.

questions.text: The autopsy finding of a person who died due to hanging showed the presence of hemorrhages in the intervertebral disc of the lumbar spine. What are these called?
questions.solution:
Simon’s haemorrhage / Simon’s sign / Simon’s symptom is streaky haemorrhage on the anterior aspects of the intervertebral disc, particularly in the lower thoracic and lumbar spine. It is frequently observed in cases of hanging.

Simon haemorrhage has been shown to occur also in the course of traumatic overextension of the spinal column, e.g. in traffic accidents or as a post-mortem artefact in decomposed bodies.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to you with complaints of nasal obstruction and frequent nose bleeds. CT scan shows Holman-Miller sign. You suspect a benign tumour of the nasopharynx. What is its most common site of origin?

choices.text: Anterior wall of the sphenoid bone

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with a CT scan showing the Holman-Miller sign is suggestive of the diagnosis of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA). It most commonly arises from the sphenopalatine foramen. 

From here the tumour grows into the:

  • Nasal cavity
  • Nasopharynx
  • Pterygopalatine fossa
  • Pterygomaxillary fossa
  • Infratemporal fossa

Given below is CT showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus- Holman-Miller sign.

questions.text: Most abundant cytosolic protein is
questions.solution:
Most abundant intracellular / cytosolic protein – Actin

Collagen is most abundant protein but it is extracellular. Most abundant overall and extracellular protein – Collagen

An actin protein is the monomeric subunit of two types of filaments in cells: microfilaments, one of the three major components of the cytoskeleton, and thin filaments, part of the contractile apparatus in muscle cells. Actin protein can be present as either a free monomer called G-actin (globular) or as part of a linear polymer microfilament called F-actin (filamentous).

  • Actin microfilaments are 5- to 9-nm diameter fibrils formed from the globular protein actin (G-actin), the most abundant cytosolic protein in cells. The G-actin monomers noncovalently polymerize into long filaments (F-actin) that intertwine to form double-stranded helices with a defined polarity; new globular subunits are added (or lost) at the “positive” end of the strand.
  • In muscle cells, the filamentous protein myosin binds to actin, and moves along it, driven by ATP hydrolysis (the basis of muscle contraction).
  • In non-muscle cells, F-actin assembles via an assortment of actin-binding proteins into well-organized bundles and networks that control cell shape and movement.

questions.text: Which area of the retina has the highest concentration of rods?
questions.solution:
Mid-periphery of the retina has the highest concentration of rods.

The following table lists the differences between rods and cones

Property Rods Cones
Number Most numerous (120 million) Far fewer in number (6 million)
Location Mid-peripheral retina Fovea
Function
  • Night vision
  • Motion sense
  • Peripheral vision
  • Day vision
  • Colour vision
  • Central and fine vision
Dysfunction symptoms
  • Nyctalopia
  • Peripheral field loss
  • Poor central vision
  • Dyschromatopsia
  • Hemeralopia

questions.text: Which of the following is the smallest diameter of the fetal head?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the bitemporal diameter is the smallest. It is the distance between the anteroinferior ends of the coronal suture and usually measures 8 cm. This is the smallest engaging diameter.

Option A: The biparietal diameter is a transverse diameter between two parietal eminences, measuring 9.5cm.

Option B: The suboccipitofrontal diameter is an anteroposterior diameter, measuring 10 cm. 

Option C: The suboccipitobregmatic diameter is an anteroposterior diameter, measuring 9.5 cm. 

Note: The bimastoid diameter is a transverse diameter. It is the smallest diameter in the fetal skull at about 7.5 cm. However it is not clinically relevant as it does not engage.

Related Pearl: Fetal Skull Dimensions

Note: 

Shortest diameters of fetal skull: Bimastoid - 7.5 cm (doesn't engage) < Bitemporal - 8 cm

Longest diameter of fetal skull: Mentovertical 14 cm > Submentovertical / occipitofrontal - 11.5cm

questions.text: In a bacterial growth curve, the period in which maximum cell size is obtained is _____
questions.solution:
The bacterial growth curve is characterized by an initial lag phase, followed by log phase or exponential growth phase, then reaching a stationary phase followed by phase of decline.

  1. Lag phase: It is the initial period of time required for adaptation to the new environment during which necessary enzymes and metabolic intermediates are built up in adequate quantities for multiplication. Hence by the end of lag phase, maximum cell size is obtained
  2. Log phase: Cells start dividing exponentially or by geometric progression with time
  3. Stationary phase: The viable count remains stationary as an equilibrium exists between the dying and the newly formed cells.
  4. Phase of decline: Cell population decreases in this phase due to cell death.

questions.text: Which is the most widely used instrument to measure humidity?
questions.solution:
The most widely used instrument to measure humidity is the dry and wet bulb hygrometer.

Related Pearl: Humidity

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

Relative humidity (RH):

  • It is the ratio of the actual water vapor content to the maximum water vapor content in the air required for saturation of air at a given temperature and pressure. It is expressed as a percentage.
  • RH = Actual water vapor content x 100/ Total water vapor content
  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections. 

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers - most widely used instrument
  • Sling or whirling psychrometers

The following image depicts a whirling psychrometer:

The following image depicts an Assmann psychrometer:

The following image depicts a dry and wet hygrometer:

questions.text: An 8-month old male child presented with delayed motor milestones. He was born at 28 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 1200 grams. A diagnosis of cerebral palsy is made following investigations. An MRI scan of the brain revealed periventricular leukomalacia. Which of the following subtypes of cerebral palsy is most likely in this child?
questions.solution:
The most likely subtype in this child with delayed motor milestones and a history of prematurity and low birth weight is spastic diplegia. This is because the most common sequelae of periventricular leukomalacia (PVL) is spastic diplegia. PVL is the ischemia of white matter adjacent to the lateral ventricles of the brain.

Cerebral palsy

It is a group of disorders, affecting movement or posture, due to non-progressive disturbances occurring in the developing fetal brain. These could be due to hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy. The most common subtype of cerebral palsy is spastic diplegia.

Cerebral palsy subtype Pathology
Spastic diplegia Periventricular leukomalacia
Spastic quadriplegia Parasagittal brain injury
Spastic hemiplegia Middle cerebral artery territory infarction
Dyskinetic cerebral palsy Basal ganglia

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the various anatomical positions of the appendix?

choices.text: Tenderness may be elicited on the immediate right of the umbilicus in post-ileal appendicitis
The most common location of the base of the appendix is retro-caecal
An inflamed pelvic appendix may cause an increase in frequency of micturition
Post-ileal appendicitis may have diarrhoea as a presenting complaint

questions.solution:
The base of the appendix is found at the confluence of the three taeniae coli of the caecum. Its position is constant. Conversely, the tip of the appendix can be found in many positions ( retrocaecal being the most common)

The taeniae coli fuse to form the longitudinal muscle coat of the appendix. During surgery, gentle traction at the taenia coli, leads the surgeon to the base of the appendix.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best plane for the measurement of volume of hippocampus?
questions.solution:
The best plane for measurement of the volume of the hippocampus is the coronal plane, angled perpendicular to the long axis of the hippocampus in MRI, which is represented by the image marked B.

Coronal MRI is taken perpendicular to the long axis of the temporal horn can be used to measure:

  • Volume of hippocampus - measured in Alzheimer's disease and medial temporal seizures
  • Medial temporal lobe atrophy (MTA)

The planes of MRI are given below.

Image marked as D shows the axial section of a CT.

questions.text: Patients diagnosed with which variant of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis are likely to have the worst prognosis?
questions.solution:
The collapsing variant of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is associated with the worst prognosis.

There are 5 variants of FSGS: 

  • Collapsing variant - poor prognosis
  • Glomerular tip variant - good prognosis
  • Cellular variant
  • Perihilar variant
  • Not otherwise specified - most common

Given below is a histological image of collapsing glomerulopathy showing the involvement of the entire glomerular tuft and proliferation of visceral epithelial cells.

questions.text: The prevalence of delirium is the highest in which group of patients?
questions.solution:
Delirium is a common disorder, with most incidence and prev­alence rates reported in the elderly age group.

Population Prevalence % Incidence %
Critical care unit patients 16 16–83 
Emergency department 7–10 N/A 
Terminally ill cancer patients 23–28 83
Institutionalised elderly 44 33

questions.text: What is the longest part of the fallopian tube?
questions.solution:
The longest and widest part of the fallopian tube is the ampulla (5 cm).

Related Pearl: Fallopian tube

Gross anatomy:

The fallopian tube is divided into the following parts:

  • Intramural/Interstitial portion:  
    • Intrauterine
    • The narrowest and shortest part
  • Isthmus:
    • The most common site for tubectomy
  • Ampulla:
    • The longest and widest part
    • The most common site for - fertilization and ectopic pregnancy
  • Infundibulum

Histology:

The ampulla, isthmus and infundibulum are extrauterine. They're covered by three layers: 

  • Mesosalpinx - It is the peritoneal layer. Also called serosa.
  • Myosalpinx - It contains smooth muscle and has 2 layers:
    • Inner circular 
    • Outer longitudinal
  • Endosalpinx - It is the mucosal layer. It has the following features:
    • Numerous branching folds, filling the entire lumen
    • Basement membrane
    • Ciliated, columnar epithelium 
    • Peg cells - non-ciliated epithelium. They help in the capacitation of sperms.

questions.text: Which of the following is the largest trematode infecting humans?
questions.solution:
Fasciolopsis buski is the largest trematode infecting humans.

It is also known as giant intestinal fluke. It measures about 20–75 mm in length.

The adult worm is ovoid in shape with a small oral sucker and a large acetabulum. It has no cephalic cone.

Note:

  • Largest trematode infecting humans – Fasciolopsis buski.
  • Smallest trematode infecting humans – Heterophyes.

questions.text: Which pattern of microcalcification seen in a patient’s mammography report would indicate the maximum risk of malignancy?
questions.solution:
Cluster microcalcification in mammography indicates the maximum risk of malignancy.

Breast cancer, the most common cancer globally, accounts for 2.3 million new cases annually, with 70% of deaths occurring in resource-constrained areas due to late detection. WHO’s Global Breast Cancer Initiative (GBCI) aims to reduce mortality by 2.5% annually by 2040 through early detection, timely diagnosis, and comprehensive care. This Breast Cancer Awareness Month, under the theme 'No one should face breast cancer alone' highlights the need for early detection, patient support, and stronger partnerships to address disparities and improve outcomes.

Related Pearl: Types of microcalcification indicating malignancy

In decreasing order of risk of malignancy-

  • Cluster microcalcification (maximum risk)
  • Linear microcalcification
  • Segmental microcalcification
  • Diffuse microcalcification (minimum risk)

questions.text: Which of the following reactions occurs most frequently in patients undergoing blood transfusions?
questions.solution:
Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR) is the most frequently occurring transfusion reaction.

Related Pearl: Blood Transfusion Reactions

Immunological Transfusion Reactions             

Reaction
(Onset)

 Mechanism Presentation Management

Anaphylactic transfusion reaction

(Seconds-minutes)

Common in IgA deficient recipients 

Shock, respiratory distress, angioedema

Stop transfusion immediately, give epinephrine

Prevention – using IgA deficient plasma and washed cellular blood components

Allergic/ Urticarial transfusion reaction

(Within 2-3 hours)

Recipient IgE against donor components causing mast cell activation

Urticaria, flushing, pruritus

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction

(within 6h)

 

(Most common complication of blood transfusion)

Antibodies against donor WBC and HLA antigens (sensitization)

Cytokine accumulation during blood storage

More common in multipally transfused patients and multiparous women

Fever and chills sometimes with mild dyspnoea

Antihistamines and antipyretics

Transfusion can be stopped if symptoms are severe

Prevention: Leukoreduced products

Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)

(1-6 hours)

Anti-HLA type 2 antibodies in donor plasma bind recipient WBCs, increase capillary permeability

Hypoxia, non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema

CXR: Bilateral interstitial infiltrates

Stop transfusion immediately

Supportive care

Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction

(during transfusion to within 24h)

ABO incompatibility

(Type 2 hypersensitivity)

Pre-existing high affinity IgM antibodies rapidly induce complement mediated lysis, intra-vascular hemolysis, and hemoglobinuria

Fever, chills, flank/back pain

Sense of impending doom

Hemoglobinuria

DIC, Renal failure

Coomb’s test positive, pink plasma

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction

occurs after 24 hours ( usually 2 weeks )

Recipients have prior exposure to RBC antigens. After the transfusion, anamnestic response results in antibody production

Typically caused by IgG antibodies to foreign protein antigens and are associated with laboratory features of hemolysis.

Mild fever, hemolytic anemia

Coomb’s test positive

Screening for new antibodies positive

Supportive care

Additional transfusions if needed

Non-immune mediated transfusion reactions are as follows:

  • Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO)
  • Hypothermia
  • Electrolyte abnormality- hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia
  • Iron overload
  • Transient hypotension
  • Immunomodulation
  • Blood-borne infections
